A.levelDescription: 2-3 years below expected level - Focus on basic understanding of what drugs are and how they affect the body
whatYouWillLearn: What drugs are and different types
How drugs affect the body and brain
Legal versus illegal drugs
Why understanding drugs matters for health

sections.title: What Are Drugs?
sections.content:
A drug is any substance that changes how your body or mind works.

Drugs can be:
- Medicines that help you get better when sick
- Substances people use to change how they feel
- Things found in everyday products (caffeine in coffee)

Drugs are everywhere:
- Panadol for pain is a drug
- Coffee contains a drug (caffeine)
- Alcohol is a drug
- Cigarettes contain a drug (nicotine)
- Illegal substances like cannabis are drugs

Not all drugs are bad:
- Many drugs help people stay healthy
- Medicines treat illness and pain
- Some drugs are prescribed by doctors

But all drugs can be harmful:
- Even helpful drugs can be dangerous if used wrongly
- Taking too much of any drug can cause harm
- Mixing drugs can be dangerous

sections.title: Types of Drugs
sections.content:
Drugs are grouped by what they do to your body.

Depressants (downers):
- Slow down your brain and body
- Make you feel relaxed or sleepy
- Examples: alcohol, cannabis, heroin, some medications
- Can slow breathing dangerously

Stimulants (uppers):
- Speed up your brain and body
- Make you feel more awake or energetic
- Examples: caffeine, nicotine, cocaine, ice (methamphetamine)
- Can make your heart beat too fast

Hallucinogens:
- Change how you see, hear, or feel things
- Can cause seeing or hearing things that aren't there
- Examples: magic mushrooms, LSD
- Can be very scary or unpredictable

Analgesics (painkillers):
- Block pain
- Examples: paracetamol, ibuprofen, codeine, morphine
- Stronger ones can be addictive

Some drugs fit in more than one category. Cannabis, for example, is mainly a depressant but can also cause mild hallucinations.

sections.title: How Drugs Affect the Body
sections.content:
Drugs work by changing how your body and brain function.

How drugs get into your body:
- Swallowing (pills, drinks)
- Smoking (cigarettes, cannabis)
- Injecting (needles)
- Snorting (through the nose)
- Absorbing through skin (patches)

What happens:
1. Drug enters your body
2. Goes into your bloodstream
3. Travels to your brain and other organs
4. Changes how cells work
5. Creates effects (how you feel)
6. Body works to get rid of the drug

Effects depend on:
- The type of drug
- How much you take
- How you take it
- Your body size and health
- Whether you've eaten
- Whether you've taken other drugs

Short-term effects:
- How you feel right after taking a drug
- Usually last hours to days

Long-term effects:
- Changes from using drugs over time
- Can affect health, brain, relationships

sections.title: Legal and Illegal Drugs
sections.content:
Some drugs are legal, some are illegal. But legal doesn't mean safe.

Legal drugs (in Australia):
- Alcohol (if you're 18+)
- Tobacco and nicotine products (if you're 18+)
- Caffeine (any age)
- Prescription medicines (with a doctor's prescription)
- Over-the-counter medicines (following instructions)

Illegal drugs (in Australia):
- Cannabis (illegal in most situations)
- Cocaine
- Heroin
- Ice (methamphetamine)
- Ecstasy/MDMA
- LSD
- Magic mushrooms

Why some drugs are illegal:
- They can cause serious harm
- They're very addictive
- They affect judgment and can lead to dangerous behaviour

Important to know:
- Legal drugs still cause a lot of harm (alcohol and tobacco cause more deaths than illegal drugs)
- Using illegal drugs can lead to legal problems
- Medicines are only safe when used correctly
- Age limits exist because young brains are still developing

sections.title: Why This Matters
sections.content:
Understanding drugs helps you make informed choices.

Knowledge helps you:
- Understand risks
- Make your own decisions
- Help friends who might be in trouble
- Recognise when someone needs help

Drug use affects:
- Your health (body and mind)
- Your relationships
- Your goals and future
- Your safety

Young people and drugs:
- Young brains are still developing until about age 25
- Drugs can affect brain development
- Starting younger increases risks
- You don't have to use drugs

Where to get information:
- Trusted adults (parents, teachers, counsellors)
- Websites like druginfo.adf.org.au
- School nurse or doctor
- Kids Helpline: 1800 55 1800

You don't need to use drugs to fit in or deal with problems. There are always other options.

keyTerms.definition: Any substance that changes how your body or mind works
A drug that slows down the brain and body
A drug that speeds up the brain and body
A drug that is allowed by law, though may have age restrictions
A drug that is against the law to use, possess, or sell
An unwanted effect of a drug, separate from its main purpose

caseStudy.title: Understanding Jordan's Question
caseStudy.scenario: Jordan's older sibling says alcohol is fine because it's legal, but weed should be avoided because it's illegal. Jordan is confused because they've heard that alcohol causes a lot of harm too. Jordan wants to understand why some drugs are legal and others aren't, and whether legal means safe.
questions: Is Jordan's sibling correct that legal means safe?
Why might alcohol be legal while cannabis is mostly illegal?
What would you tell Jordan about the difference between legal and safe?
caseStudy.keyLearning: Legal status doesn't determine how harmful a drug is. Alcohol and tobacco, though legal, cause more deaths than illegal drugs. Laws about drugs are influenced by history, culture, and politics, not just harm. All drugs carry risks, and being informed helps you make better decisions.

remember.question: What is a depressant?
remember.sampleAnswer: A depressant is a drug that slows down the brain and body, making you feel relaxed or sleepy. Examples include alcohol and cannabis.

understand.question: Explain why legal drugs can still be harmful.
understand.sampleAnswer: Legal drugs like alcohol and tobacco can still cause serious harm because 'legal' doesn't mean 'safe.' Alcohol can damage the liver, cause addiction, and lead to accidents. Tobacco causes cancer and heart disease. They're legal because of history and culture, but they still cause health problems when used.

apply.question: Someone tells you that energy drinks are fine because they're legal. How would you respond using what you've learned?
apply.sampleAnswer: I would explain that energy drinks contain caffeine, which is a stimulant drug. Just because something is legal doesn't mean it's completely safe. Energy drinks can cause problems like a racing heart, trouble sleeping, and anxiety, especially if you have too many. Legal status and safety are different things.

unistructural.question: Name one way drugs can enter the body.
unistructural.sampleAnswer: Drugs can enter the body by swallowing, smoking, injecting, snorting, or absorbing through the skin.

multistructural.question: List three types of drugs based on their effects.
multistructural.sampleAnswer: Depressants (slow down the body), stimulants (speed up the body), hallucinogens (change how you see or hear things), and analgesics (painkillers).

relational.question: Explain the connection between how a drug enters your body and how quickly it affects you.
relational.sampleAnswer: The way a drug enters your body affects how fast it works. Injecting and smoking get drugs into your bloodstream very quickly, so effects happen fast. Swallowing is slower because the drug has to be digested first. Faster methods can be more dangerous because there's less time to react if something goes wrong.

studentReflection: What did I learn about drugs that surprised me?
Why might it be important to know about different types of drugs?
Where could I find reliable information if I had questions about drugs?

B.levelDescription: 1 year below expected level - Building understanding of how drugs work and factors influencing their effects
whatYouWillLearn: How drugs interact with the brain
Factors that influence drug effects
The difference between use, misuse, and dependence
How to access reliable information about drugs

sections.title: How Drugs Affect the Brain
sections.content:
Understanding how drugs work in the brain helps explain why they can be dangerous.

The brain's communication system:
- The brain has billions of nerve cells (neurons)
- Neurons communicate using chemicals called neurotransmitters
- Drugs interfere with this communication

Key neurotransmitters:

Dopamine:
- Makes you feel pleasure and reward
- Normally released when you do enjoyable things (eating, exercising, socialising)
- Many drugs flood the brain with dopamine
- This is why drugs can feel good - but it's not natural or sustainable

Serotonin:
- Affects mood, sleep, and appetite
- Some drugs affect serotonin levels

GABA:
- Calms the brain down
- Depressants increase GABA effects
- This is why they make you feel relaxed

Noradrenaline:
- Involved in alertness and energy
- Stimulants increase its effects
- This is why they make you feel awake

Why drugs can be harmful:
- They trick the brain into releasing too much of these chemicals
- The brain tries to balance itself by making less
- Over time, you need more drug to feel normal
- This is how dependence develops

sections.title: Factors Affecting Drug Effects
sections.content:
The same drug can affect different people differently. Many factors influence this.

Drug-related factors:
- Type of drug
- Amount taken (dose)
- Purity (what else is in it)
- How it's taken (swallowed, smoked, injected)
- Whether combined with other drugs

Person-related factors:

Body size and composition:
- Smaller people are affected more by the same amount
- Body fat affects how drugs are stored

Tolerance:
- With repeated use, the same dose has less effect
- People take more to get the same feeling
- This increases risk of harm

Genetics:
- Some people are genetically more affected by certain drugs
- Family history of addiction increases risk

Mental health:
- People with mental health issues may react differently
- Drugs can worsen mental health conditions

Situation factors:

Food:
- Eating before drinking alcohol slows its absorption
- Empty stomach means faster, stronger effects

Environment:
- Where you are and who you're with
- Feeling safe vs anxious affects experience

Expectations:
- What you expect to feel can influence what you actually feel
- Called the 'placebo effect' for drugs too

sections.title: Use, Misuse, and Dependence
sections.content:
Not all drug use is the same. Understanding the spectrum helps assess risk.

Drug use:
- Taking a drug for its intended purpose
- Taking medicine as prescribed
- Having a coffee
- May or may not be harmful depending on the drug and situation

Drug misuse:
- Using a drug in a way that causes harm
- Taking more than prescribed
- Using someone else's medication
- Drinking too much alcohol
- Using illegal drugs

Drug dependence:
- Needing a drug to feel normal
- Body has adapted to the drug being present

Physical dependence:
- Body needs the drug to function normally
- Withdrawal symptoms when you stop (sweating, shaking, nausea)
- Common with alcohol, opioids, benzodiazepines

Psychological dependence:
- Feeling like you need the drug to cope
- Strong cravings
- Using to deal with emotions or situations
- Can happen with any drug

Addiction:
- Compulsive drug use despite negative consequences
- Loss of control over use
- Drug use becomes top priority
- A recognised medical condition

The path isn't inevitable:
- Not everyone who uses drugs becomes dependent
- Some drugs are more addictive than others
- Early use, heavy use, and genetic factors increase risk
- Understanding risk helps make informed choices

sections.title: Common Drugs in Australia
sections.content:
Understanding the most commonly used drugs in Australia.

Alcohol:
- Most commonly used drug in Australia
- Legal for people 18+
- Depressant affecting judgment, coordination, reaction time
- Responsible for significant health burden and social harm

Tobacco and nicotine:
- Highly addictive stimulant
- Leading preventable cause of death
- Now includes vaping products (e-cigarettes)
- Legal for 18+ but age for purchase increasing

Cannabis:
- Most commonly used illegal drug
- Mainly a depressant, some hallucinogenic effects
- Can affect mental health, especially in young people
- Illegal in most situations (some medical exceptions)

Methamphetamine (ice, crystal meth):
- Powerful stimulant
- Highly addictive
- Can cause psychosis and other mental health issues
- Increasing concern in Australia

MDMA (ecstasy):
- Stimulant with some hallucinogenic properties
- Often used at parties and festivals
- Risks include overheating, dehydration, serotonin syndrome
- Unpredictable strength and purity

Opioids:
- Include heroin and prescription painkillers
- Highly addictive
- Risk of overdose (slowed breathing)
- Prescription opioid misuse is a growing concern

sections.title: Finding Reliable Information
sections.content:
Not all information about drugs is accurate. Knowing where to find reliable sources is important.

Reliable sources:

Australian websites:
- Alcohol and Drug Foundation (adf.org.au)
- Drug Info (druginfo.adf.org.au)
- Positive Choices (positivechoices.org.au)
- Your Room (yourroom.health.nsw.gov.au)

Health professionals:
- Doctors and nurses
- School nurses and counsellors
- Alcohol and drug services

Helplines:
- DirectLine (Victoria): 1800 888 236
- ADIS (other states have similar services)
- Kids Helpline: 1800 55 1800

Unreliable sources:
- Random websites or social media
- Friends (may not have accurate information)
- Dealers (have reasons to minimise risks)

How to evaluate information:
- Who wrote it? (Government, health organisation, random person?)
- What's the purpose? (Education or selling something?)
- Is it up to date?
- Does it cite evidence?
- Does it match what other reliable sources say?

Why accurate information matters:
- Helps you understand real risks
- Allows informed decisions
- Scare tactics don't work and may backfire
- Honest information builds trust

keyTerms.definition: Chemical messengers in the brain that allow nerve cells to communicate
Brain chemical associated with pleasure and reward
When repeated drug use leads to needing more to get the same effect
Physical or psychological need for a drug to feel normal
Physical and psychological symptoms when stopping a drug the body has become dependent on
Compulsive drug use despite negative consequences, recognised as a medical condition

caseStudy.title: Sam's Research
caseStudy.scenario: Sam is doing a school project on drugs. They find lots of different information online - some says cannabis is completely safe and natural, while other sources say it's extremely dangerous. Sam also finds information from a government health website that seems more balanced. Sam isn't sure what to believe.
questions: Why might Sam be finding such different information?
What makes the government health website more reliable?
What questions should Sam ask when evaluating drug information?
caseStudy.keyLearning: Drug information varies widely in reliability. Some sources minimise risks, others exaggerate them. Reliable sources like government health websites aim to provide balanced, evidence-based information. When evaluating information, consider who wrote it, their purpose, whether it cites evidence, and whether it matches other reliable sources.

remember.question: What is the difference between physical and psychological dependence?
remember.sampleAnswer: Physical dependence is when your body needs the drug to function normally and you get withdrawal symptoms without it. Psychological dependence is when you feel like you need the drug to cope emotionally and have strong cravings, but without the same physical symptoms.

understand.question: Explain why tolerance can make drug use more dangerous over time.
understand.sampleAnswer: Tolerance means you need more of a drug to get the same effect. This is dangerous because people take higher doses, which increases the risk of overdose and side effects. The body may tolerate some effects but not others - for example, someone might tolerate the 'high' from opioids but not the effect on breathing, leading to overdose. Tolerance also makes it harder to stop because the body has adapted to having the drug.

apply.question: Someone says they'll be fine drinking because they've built up a tolerance to alcohol. What would you explain to them?
apply.sampleAnswer: I'd explain that tolerance doesn't make alcohol safer - it actually increases risk. While they might not feel as drunk, alcohol is still damaging their liver and other organs. They might drink more because they don't feel the effects, causing more harm. Tolerance to feeling drunk doesn't mean tolerance to other effects like liver damage. They're also at risk of becoming dependent because their body has adapted to alcohol.

analyse.question: Analyse why a person's expectations about a drug might affect their experience.
analyse.sampleAnswer: Expectations affect drug experiences because the brain is powerful at influencing perception. If someone expects a drug to make them relaxed, they're more likely to feel relaxed. This works both ways - expecting a bad experience can contribute to anxiety or a bad trip. Expectations are influenced by what they've heard, past experiences, and the environment. This is why drug effects can vary so much between people even with the same drug. It's similar to how placebo effects work in medicine - belief influences experience.

unistructural.question: What neurotransmitter is associated with pleasure and reward?
unistructural.sampleAnswer: Dopamine is the neurotransmitter associated with pleasure and reward.

multistructural.question: List four factors that can influence how a drug affects someone.
multistructural.sampleAnswer: Body size, tolerance from previous use, the amount taken (dose), how the drug is taken (swallowed, smoked, injected), whether it's combined with other drugs, mental health state, whether they've eaten, and genetics.

relational.question: Explain the relationship between dopamine release from drugs and the development of addiction.
relational.sampleAnswer: When drugs release large amounts of dopamine, the brain experiences intense pleasure. To balance this, the brain reduces its natural dopamine production and sensitivity. Over time, normal activities that used to be enjoyable produce less pleasure because the dopamine system has adapted to the drug's effects. People then need the drug just to feel normal, not just to feel good. This drives continued use and increases doses, leading to addiction. The brain has essentially been rewired to prioritise the drug over natural rewards.

extendedAbstract.question: Evaluate whether scare tactics are an effective approach to drug education for young people.
extendedAbstract.sampleAnswer: Research suggests scare tactics are generally not effective for drug education. When young people encounter exaggerated claims and then see friends using drugs without immediate extreme consequences, they lose trust in all drug information, including accurate warnings. Scare tactics don't address why people use drugs or provide skills to navigate real situations. They may increase curiosity rather than deter use. Effective education provides accurate, balanced information; develops decision-making and refusal skills; addresses underlying reasons for use; and is age-appropriate and relevant. However, some argue that highlighting real consequences has value if done accurately. The key is honesty - acknowledging that some drug use doesn't cause immediate harm while explaining genuine long-term risks builds credibility and allows informed decisions.

studentReflection: How do I evaluate whether drug information is reliable?
Why might understanding how drugs work in the brain be useful?
What factors might make some people more vulnerable to drug problems?

C.levelDescription: At expected level - Comprehensive understanding of drug pharmacology, patterns of use, and Australian context
whatYouWillLearn: Detailed drug pharmacology and mechanisms
Patterns of drug use in Australia
Social, economic, and health impacts of drug use
Evidence-based approaches to understanding drug issues

sections.title: Drug Pharmacology
sections.content:
Understanding how drugs work at a biological level.

Routes of administration and pharmacokinetics:

Absorption:
- Oral (swallowing): Slow absorption through digestive system, 30-60 minutes to peak effects
- Intranasal (snorting): Absorbed through nasal membranes, 10-15 minutes
- Inhalation (smoking/vaping): Very rapid absorption through lungs, effects within seconds
- Intravenous (injection): Immediate absorption, highest bioavailability
- Sublingual: Under tongue, bypasses digestive system
- Transdermal: Through skin, slow and sustained release

Distribution:
- Drugs travel through bloodstream to target organs
- Blood-brain barrier filters what enters the brain
- Fat-soluble drugs can be stored in body fat (e.g., THC)

Metabolism:
- Liver primarily breaks down drugs
- Metabolites may be active or inactive
- Some drugs are 'prodrugs' - activated by metabolism

Excretion:
- Mainly through kidneys (urine)
- Also through breath, sweat, faeces
- Half-life: time for blood concentration to halve

Drug mechanisms:

Agonists:
- Mimic natural neurotransmitters
- Activate receptors
- Example: opioids activate opioid receptors

Antagonists:
- Block receptors
- Prevent natural neurotransmitters from working
- Example: naloxone blocks opioid receptors

Reuptake inhibitors:
- Prevent neurotransmitters being reabsorbed
- Increase available neurotransmitter
- Example: cocaine blocks dopamine reuptake

Release enhancers:
- Cause neurons to release more neurotransmitters
- Example: amphetamines cause dopamine release

sections.title: Patterns of Drug Use in Australia
sections.content:
Understanding drug use patterns in Australia helps contextualise the issue.

Data sources:
- National Drug Strategy Household Survey (NDSHS)
- Australian Institute of Health and Welfare
- National Drug and Alcohol Research Centre

Alcohol:
- 76% of Australians 14+ have consumed alcohol in the past year
- 25% of Australians drink at risky levels on a single occasion at least monthly
- 16% exceed lifetime risk guidelines
- Declining use among young people in recent years

Tobacco:
- 11% daily smokers (significant decline from 24% in 1991)
- Vaping increasing, especially among young people
- E-cigarette use tripled among 14-17 year olds (2016-2019)

Cannabis:
- 11.6% of Australians 14+ used in past year
- Most commonly used illegal drug
- Highest use among 18-24 year olds
- Medical cannabis now legal with prescription

Methamphetamine:
- 1.3% of Australians 14+ used in past year
- 'Ice' (crystal meth) most common form
- Use declining slightly but harm increasing

Cocaine:
- 4.2% of Australians 14+ used in past year
- Use increasing in recent years
- Highest use in major cities

Opioids:
- 0.4% used heroin in past year
- Pharmaceutical opioid misuse is significant concern
- Opioid-related deaths increasing

Trends:
- Overall illicit drug use relatively stable
- Alcohol and tobacco declining, especially in young people
- Vaping and pharmaceutical misuse increasing
- Regional variations exist

sections.title: Social and Economic Impacts
sections.content:
Drug use has significant impacts beyond individual health.

Economic costs:
- Alcohol costs Australia approximately $66 billion per year (including health, crime, lost productivity)
- Tobacco costs approximately $137 billion per year
- Illicit drugs cost approximately $27 billion per year
- Note: legal drugs cause greater economic burden than illegal drugs

Health system impacts:
- Hospital admissions for drug-related conditions
- Emergency department presentations
- Drug treatment services
- Mental health services
- Ambulance responses

Social impacts:

Family and relationships:
- Family conflict and breakdown
- Domestic violence (40% involves alcohol)
- Child protection concerns
- Financial stress

Community:
- Crime (property crime, violence, drug dealing)
- Antisocial behaviour
- Public safety concerns
- Stigma affecting help-seeking

Workplace:
- Absenteeism
- Reduced productivity
- Workplace injuries
- Economic costs to employers

Disparity in impacts:
- Not evenly distributed across society
- Lower socioeconomic areas often more affected
- Indigenous communities experience disproportionate harms
- Regional areas may have less access to services

Legal consequences:
- Criminal records affecting employment and travel
- Imprisonment
- Drug driving penalties
- Impact on future opportunities

sections.title: Drug-Related Harms
sections.content:
Different types of harms from drug use.

Acute harms (short-term):

Overdose:
- Taking too much of a drug
- Depressant overdose: slowed breathing, unconsciousness, death
- Stimulant overdose: heart attack, stroke, overheating
- Risk increased with unknown purity and poly-drug use

Intoxication-related:
- Accidents and injuries
- Violence (as perpetrator or victim)
- Sexual assault (vulnerability when intoxicated)
- Drug driving crashes
- Risky sexual behaviour

Adverse reactions:
- Allergic reactions
- Bad trips (hallucinogens)
- Drug-induced psychosis
- Panic attacks

Chronic harms (long-term):

Physical health:
- Liver disease (alcohol)
- Lung disease (smoking)
- Heart disease (stimulants)
- Infectious diseases (injecting - hepatitis C, HIV)
- Cancer
- Brain damage

Mental health:
- Depression and anxiety
- Psychosis (cannabis, methamphetamine)
- Cognitive impairment
- Mental health conditions worsened

Dependence:
- Physical and psychological addiction
- Impact on daily functioning
- Withdrawal when stopping

Social harms:
- Relationship breakdown
- Employment problems
- Financial difficulties
- Legal issues
- Housing instability

sections.title: Evidence-Based Understanding
sections.content:
Applying evidence to understand drug issues accurately.

Harm reduction principles:
- Accepts that some drug use will occur
- Focuses on reducing harm rather than eliminating use
- Evidence-based and pragmatic
- Non-judgmental approach
- Examples: needle exchange, drug checking, supervised injecting rooms

Understanding risk:

Absolute vs relative risk:
- Some activities are riskier than others
- Not all drug use results in harm
- Frequency, amount, and patterns matter

Dose-response:
- Generally, more drug = more risk
- But not always linear
- Threshold effects (some harm only occurs above certain levels)

Vulnerability factors:
- Age (young brains more vulnerable)
- Mental health history
- Family history of addiction
- Trauma history
- Social circumstances

Drug comparisons:
- Different drugs have different risk profiles
- Comparing drugs on multiple dimensions:
  - Acute toxicity (how easy to overdose)
  - Dependence potential
  - Chronic health harms
  - Social harms
- No drug is completely safe; some are riskier than others

Debunking myths:
- 'Gateway drug' theory has limited evidence
- Not everyone who tries drugs becomes addicted
- Drug users are not all the same
- Drug problems can affect anyone
- Recovery is possible

keyTerms.definition: How the body absorbs, distributes, metabolises, and excretes drugs
The time it takes for the concentration of a drug in the blood to reduce by half
A substance that activates a receptor to produce a biological response
Approach focused on reducing negative consequences of drug use rather than solely on preventing use
Using multiple drugs at the same or similar time, which can increase risks
Selective barrier protecting the brain from many substances in the blood

caseStudy.title: Understanding Risk
caseStudy.scenario: A group of friends is discussing drug risk. One says alcohol is safer because it's legal. Another says cannabis is safer because it's 'natural.' A third says all drugs are equally dangerous. They're trying to work out which drugs are riskiest and why, and how to think about this accurately.
questions: Evaluate each friend's claim about drug safety.
What factors should be considered when comparing drug risks?
How would you help the group think about this more accurately?
Why is context important when assessing drug risk?
caseStudy.keyLearning: Drug risk comparisons are complex and depend on multiple factors including acute toxicity, addiction potential, pattern of use, and individual vulnerabilities. Legal status and 'naturalness' don't determine safety. Evidence-based understanding acknowledges that different drugs pose different types and levels of risk, and context matters significantly.

remember.question: What is the most commonly used illegal drug in Australia?
remember.sampleAnswer: Cannabis is the most commonly used illegal drug in Australia, with 11.6% of Australians aged 14 and over having used it in the past year.

understand.question: Explain how route of administration affects drug effects.
understand.sampleAnswer: Route of administration determines how quickly a drug reaches the brain and how much of it gets there. Injecting and smoking deliver drugs very quickly (seconds to minutes), producing intense effects but also higher risk of overdose and addiction. Swallowing is slower (30-60 minutes) because the drug must pass through the digestive system, which also breaks down some of the drug. Faster routes tend to be more addictive because the brain makes stronger associations between the drug and pleasure.

apply.question: Using your understanding of pharmacology, explain why drinking alcohol on an empty stomach has stronger effects.
apply.sampleAnswer: When the stomach is empty, alcohol passes quickly into the small intestine where it's absorbed rapidly into the bloodstream. Food slows gastric emptying, keeping alcohol in the stomach longer where absorption is slower. Food also dilutes the alcohol concentration. The result is that the same amount of alcohol on an empty stomach produces a faster rise in blood alcohol concentration and more intense effects. This is why eating before drinking is recommended to slow absorption.

analyse.question: Analyse why tobacco and alcohol cause more deaths than illegal drugs despite being legal.
analyse.sampleAnswer: Several factors explain this: 1) Availability - legal status means more people use them more frequently, creating larger population-level harm even if individual-use risk is similar or lower. 2) Patterns of use - legal drugs are used regularly and daily more often than most illegal drugs. 3) Long-term health effects - both cause cancers and chronic diseases that develop over decades of use. 4) Social normalisation - their acceptability means less stigma around use, more use, and historically less intervention. 5) Numbers - the absolute number of users is vastly higher. This illustrates that harm at population level depends on both individual-level risk AND how many people are exposed.

evaluate.question: Evaluate the claim that harm reduction approaches are 'enabling' drug use.
evaluate.sampleAnswer: This claim is not supported by evidence. Harm reduction aims to reduce negative consequences rather than solely prevent use. Evidence shows that harm reduction services (like needle exchanges and supervised injecting facilities) do not increase drug use but do reduce harms like overdose deaths and disease transmission. They also engage people with health services who otherwise might not access care. Critics argue it sends a mixed message, but research doesn't support this - people who use drugs understand that health services aren't endorsing drug use. Harm reduction acknowledges reality: some people will use drugs regardless of prohibition, and keeping them alive creates opportunities for recovery. It's a pragmatic, evidence-based approach rather than 'enabling.'

create.question: Design a framework for comparing the risks of different drugs that accounts for multiple dimensions of harm.
create.sampleAnswer: Framework dimensions: 1) Acute toxicity - how dangerous is a single use? How easy is it to overdose? What's the margin between active dose and lethal dose? 2) Addiction potential - how quickly does dependence develop? How severe is withdrawal? 3) Chronic health harms - long-term physical effects on organs and systems. 4) Mental health impacts - risk of mental health conditions or worsening existing ones. 5) Social harms - effects on relationships, employment, finances. 6) Intoxication harms - accidents, violence, risk-taking while impaired. 7) Method-specific harms - risks from how the drug is taken (injection, smoking). Application: rate each drug on each dimension, acknowledge that people may weight dimensions differently, and recognise that context (patterns of use, individual factors) affects actual risk.

unistructural.question: What is harm reduction?
unistructural.sampleAnswer: Harm reduction is an approach focused on reducing the negative consequences of drug use rather than solely preventing use.

multistructural.question: List four ways drugs can enter the body and one characteristic of each.
multistructural.sampleAnswer: Oral/swallowing (slow absorption, 30-60 minutes), inhalation/smoking (very fast, seconds), intravenous/injection (immediate and highest bioavailability), intranasal/snorting (moderate speed, 10-15 minutes).

relational.question: Explain the relationship between drug purity and overdose risk.
relational.sampleAnswer: Illegal drugs have unpredictable purity - the actual drug content varies significantly. Users develop tolerance to their usual dose and strength. When purity unexpectedly increases, the same volume contains more active drug than expected, leading to overdose. This is why drug-checking services are a harm reduction tool - knowing actual content allows more informed dosing. Purity variation is a key reason illegal drug use is riskier than it might otherwise be, and why periods of new supply or drought can see overdose spikes.

extendedAbstract.question: Critically analyse the statement: 'The war on drugs has failed - we should legalise everything.'
extendedAbstract.sampleAnswer: This requires nuanced analysis. Evidence suggests prohibition hasn't eliminated drug use and creates harms: criminal records affecting lives, dangerous unregulated supply, barriers to help-seeking, massive incarceration costs, and empowerment of criminal organisations. Some harms of drug use are actually harms of prohibition. However, 'legalise everything' is simplistic. Drugs have different risk profiles; regulations could vary accordingly. Decriminalisation (removing criminal penalties for personal use while keeping sales illegal) differs from full legalisation with regulated supply. Portugal's decriminalisation hasn't increased use and has reduced HIV and overdose deaths. Cannabis legalisation in various jurisdictions provides data showing no disaster scenarios but some concerns (commercialisation, marketing to youth). Full legalisation of high-harm drugs like methamphetamine raises different concerns. A nuanced position recognises drug policy reform is needed, prohibition has failed, but thoughtful regulation (not simply 'legalise everything') is required, with different approaches for different drugs.

studentReflection: How does understanding pharmacology change how I think about drug effects?
What surprised me about drug use patterns in Australia?
How do evidence-based approaches differ from what I previously assumed about drugs?

D.levelDescription: 1 year above expected level - Advanced understanding of drug policy, neurobiology of addiction, and systemic factors
whatYouWillLearn: Neurobiology of addiction and recovery
Drug policy approaches and their effectiveness
Social determinants of drug-related harm
Critical analysis of drug discourses

sections.title: Neurobiology of Addiction
sections.content:
Understanding addiction as a brain condition.

Brain changes in addiction:

Reward system adaptation:
- Initial use: drugs trigger dopamine release far exceeding natural rewards
- With repeated use: brain downregulates dopamine receptors
- Result: reduced pleasure from natural rewards (anhedonia)
- Need drug to feel 'normal,' not just to feel 'high'

Prefrontal cortex changes:
- Region involved in decision-making and impulse control
- Chronic drug use impairs prefrontal function
- Explains difficulty controlling use despite intention to stop
- Takes time to recover even after stopping

Stress system sensitisation:
- Extended amygdala involved in negative emotions
- Becomes hyperactive in addiction
- Drives drug-seeking to relieve negative states
- Explains why stress is major relapse trigger

Memory and conditioning:
- Hippocampus and basal ganglia create powerful drug-context associations
- Environmental cues trigger cravings
- Explains why being in certain places or with certain people triggers urges
- These memories persist even after long abstinence

Allostasis model:
- Addiction shifts brain's set-point for reward
- Drug becomes necessary to maintain stability
- Without drug, system is in deficit state
- Recovery involves resetting this altered baseline

Recovery neuroscience:
- Brain has plasticity - can change
- Many changes can reverse with sustained abstinence
- Recovery is possible but takes time
- Understanding neurobiology reduces stigma: addiction is brain-based, not moral failure

sections.title: Drug Policy Approaches
sections.content:
Different approaches to drug policy and their evidence base.

Prohibition model:
- Drugs are illegal; penalties for use, possession, and supply
- Aims to deter use through criminalisation
- Evidence: hasn't eliminated use; creates secondary harms; costly to enforce
- Australia largely operates on this model for illegal drugs

Harm reduction model:
- Accepts some drug use will occur
- Focuses on reducing associated harms
- Doesn't require abstinence as prerequisite for support
- Examples: needle exchange, naloxone distribution, drug checking, supervised injecting
- Evidence: reduces overdose deaths, HIV, hepatitis C; doesn't increase use

Decriminalisation:
- Removes criminal penalties for personal use
- May still have civil penalties (fines, mandatory education)
- Supply and trafficking remain illegal
- Portugal model (since 2001): treats personal use as health issue, not crime
- Evidence: Portugal saw decreased HIV, overdose deaths, incarceration; use didn't increase

Legalisation and regulation:
- Legal production, sale, and use with regulations
- Examples: alcohol, tobacco, cannabis in some jurisdictions
- Allows quality control, taxation, age restrictions
- Concerns: commercialisation, marketing, potential increased use
- Evidence emerging from cannabis legalisation: mixed results, context-dependent

Prescription/medicalisation:
- Drugs available through medical system
- Examples: heroin-assisted treatment in some countries, medical cannabis
- Allows supervised access for dependent users
- Evidence: heroin-assisted treatment reduces crime, improves health outcomes

Australia's approach:
- National Drug Strategy: harm minimisation (supply reduction, demand reduction, harm reduction)
- In practice: heavy emphasis on law enforcement
- Some harm reduction services (needle exchange, supervised injecting in some jurisdictions)
- Medical cannabis legal with prescription
- Active debates about drug reform

sections.title: Social Determinants of Drug Harm
sections.content:
Drug-related harms are not evenly distributed - social factors matter.

Socioeconomic factors:
- Drug use occurs across all social classes
- But harms are concentrated in disadvantaged communities
- Less access to treatment and support
- Criminal justice response more likely than health response
- Poverty creates both risk factors and barriers to recovery

Indigenous communities:
- Historical trauma from colonisation
- Ongoing systemic discrimination
- Social and economic disadvantage
- Lower access to culturally appropriate services
- Higher rates of alcohol harm (despite lower use rates than non-Indigenous)
- Community-led solutions most effective

Mental health:
- Strong links between mental health issues and substance use
- 'Dual diagnosis' common but services often siloed
- Drugs may be used to self-medicate
- Drug use can trigger or worsen mental health conditions
- Integrated treatment more effective

Trauma:
- Childhood trauma increases addiction risk
- Drugs may provide temporary relief from trauma symptoms
- Trauma-informed care essential for effective treatment
- Adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) strongly predictive

Housing and employment:
- Instability makes recovery harder
- Stable housing improves treatment outcomes
- Employment provides structure, meaning, social connection
- 'Housing first' approaches show effectiveness

Stigma:
- Stigma prevents help-seeking
- Language matters ('person with addiction' vs 'addict')
- Stigma from healthcare providers affects treatment access
- Family stigma affects support
- Stigma is a barrier to effective policy

sections.title: Critical Analysis of Drug Discourses
sections.content:
How drugs are talked about shapes policy and attitudes.

Moral discourse:
- Drug use as moral failing or sin
- Users as 'bad people' making 'bad choices'
- Punitive responses as deserved consequences
- Ignores neurobiology, social factors, and structural inequality

Criminal discourse:
- Drug use and users as criminal problem
- Focus on law enforcement and incarceration
- 'War on drugs' framing
- Ignores that criminalisation creates additional harms

Medical/disease discourse:
- Addiction as chronic brain disease
- Reduces moral blame
- But may overemphasise biological factors
- Can still be stigmatising ('sick' vs 'bad')
- May understate role of environment and choice

Public health discourse:
- Drug use as health and social issue
- Evidence-based responses
- Harm reduction alongside treatment and prevention
- Considers population-level factors
- Less moralistic, more pragmatic

Social justice discourse:
- Examines who bears costs of drug policy
- Recognises racial and class disparities
- Questions whose interests are served
- Connects drug policy to broader inequality

Media representations:
- Often sensationalist ('ice epidemic' framing)
- Racialised portrayals (crack cocaine vs prescription opioids)
- Focus on criminal aspects over health
- Recovery stories rare; addiction shown as hopeless
- Shapes public opinion and policy

Deconstructing claims:
- Who benefits from this framing?
- What evidence supports or contradicts claims?
- Who is missing from the conversation?
- What alternative framings exist?

sections.title: Current Debates and Emerging Issues
sections.content:
Contemporary issues in drug policy and understanding.

Cannabis policy debates:
- Medical cannabis now legal (2016), creating pathway for broader reform
- Debate about recreational legalisation
- ACT decriminalised personal use (2020)
- Arguments for: regulation reduces harms, tax revenue, criminal justice savings
- Arguments against: potential increased use, drugged driving, commercialisation

Methamphetamine crisis:
- 'Ice' framing in media and politics
- Law enforcement vs health approach debate
- Limited effective treatments currently
- Drug-induced psychosis burdening mental health system
- Regional communities particularly affected

Opioid issues:
- Pharmaceutical opioid overprescription driving addiction
- Transition from prescription opioids to heroin for some
- Fentanyl contamination concerns
- Take-home naloxone programs expanding
- Heroin-assisted treatment discussed

Vaping and e-cigarettes:
- Rapidly increasing use especially among young people
- Debate about harm relative to cigarettes
- Gateway concerns vs harm reduction arguments
- Nicotine vape prescription requirements (2021)
- Unregulated market concerns

Drug checking:
- Testing pills at festivals to identify dangerous substances
- Operating in ACT and some other contexts
- Evidence: reduces overdoses, provides intelligence on drug supply
- Opponents claim it 'enables' drug use

Psilocybin and psychedelic therapy:
- Research on psychedelics for mental health treatment
- TGA approved psilocybin and MDMA for treatment-resistant conditions (2023)
- Challenges around training, access, and regulation
- Tension between medical and recreational frameworks

keyTerms.definition: Reduced ability to experience pleasure from activities that were previously enjoyable
Process by which the body maintains stability through change, including adapting to chronic drug exposure
Removing criminal penalties for personal drug use while keeping supply illegal
Co-occurring mental health condition and substance use disorder
Australian policy framework combining supply reduction, demand reduction, and harm reduction
Traumatic events in childhood that increase risk for health problems including addiction

caseStudy.title: Policy Reform Debate
caseStudy.scenario: A state government is considering drug policy reform. Options include: maintaining current criminal approach, decriminalising personal use (Portugal model), or moving toward regulated legalisation of cannabis. Various stakeholders have positions: police unions favour status quo, health professionals support decriminalisation, some advocate for legalisation. Concerns raised include community safety, potential increased use, impacts on young people, Indigenous community perspectives, and international treaty obligations.
questions: What evidence would you consider when evaluating each option?
How do different discourses frame the debate?
What are the potential benefits and risks of each approach?
Whose voices are often missing from these debates?
How might you balance competing values in making a recommendation?
caseStudy.keyLearning: Drug policy decisions involve value judgments alongside evidence. Different stakeholders have different interests and perspectives. Evidence from other jurisdictions provides guidance but context matters. Effective policy considers unintended consequences, implementation challenges, and who bears the costs and benefits of different approaches.

remember.question: What is the Portugal model of drug policy?
remember.sampleAnswer: Portugal decriminalised personal use of all drugs in 2001, meaning people found with small amounts face civil penalties (fines, mandatory education/treatment referral) rather than criminal charges. Supply and trafficking remain illegal. The approach treats personal drug use as a health issue rather than a criminal one.

understand.question: Explain how brain changes in addiction affect a person's ability to 'just stop' using drugs.
understand.sampleAnswer: Addiction changes the brain in ways that make stopping extremely difficult. The reward system adapts so that drugs are needed to feel normal, not just to feel good - without drugs, the person feels terrible. The prefrontal cortex, responsible for decision-making and impulse control, is impaired. The stress system becomes hyperactive, driving drug-seeking to relieve negative states. Powerful memories linking drugs to environments and emotions trigger intense cravings. These brain-based changes explain why willpower alone is often insufficient and why addiction is recognised as a medical condition rather than a simple choice.

apply.question: Apply social determinants of health thinking to explain why two people with similar drug use patterns might have very different outcomes.
apply.sampleAnswer: Social factors shape whether drug use becomes problematic and whether recovery is possible. Person A with stable housing, employment, supportive family, good mental health, and private health insurance has resources to cope - they might maintain controlled use or access treatment easily if problems develop. Person B with unstable housing, unemployment, isolation, trauma history, and in a low-income area is more likely to have use escalate, less able to access treatment, and more likely to face criminal justice responses rather than health responses. The drugs are the same, but social circumstances determine outcomes. This explains why harms concentrate in disadvantaged communities and why addressing social factors is essential for effective drug policy.

analyse.question: Analyse how media framing of 'ice epidemic' shaped public understanding and policy responses.
analyse.sampleAnswer: 'Ice epidemic' framing did several things: It created urgency and fear, potentially disproportionate to actual prevalence. The term 'epidemic' is medical but was combined with crime framing - users portrayed as violent and dangerous. This justified law enforcement responses and tough-on-crime political positions. It centred particular communities (often regional, lower-income) while downplaying similar stimulant use in professional contexts. It emphasised individual responsibility and moral failure rather than social factors. Sensationalism increased public fear but didn't necessarily improve understanding of evidence-based responses. The framing made compassionate or health-focused responses harder to advocate for. Analysing this shows how language and framing shape what responses seem reasonable.

evaluate.question: Evaluate the tension between addiction as 'brain disease' and addiction as influenced by 'choice and environment.'
evaluate.sampleAnswer: The brain disease model helpfully recognises neurobiological changes, reducing moral blame and stigma. It's scientifically accurate that addiction involves measurable brain changes. However, it can be reductive - implying a broken brain needing medical fix, underplaying that most people who use drugs don't become addicted, that recovery happens through many paths not just medical treatment, and that social factors strongly influence both addiction and recovery. The choice/environment framing captures agency and context but risks blaming individuals and ignoring neurobiology. Integrated understanding recognises: initial use involves some choice within constraints; repeated use changes the brain reducing subsequent choice capacity; environment and social factors strongly influence both vulnerability and recovery; and multiple pathways to recovery exist. This avoids both overclaiming medical model and overstating individual responsibility.

create.question: Design a drug policy that addresses the limitations of both pure prohibition and unrestricted legalisation.
create.sampleAnswer: Policy design: 1) Decriminalise personal use and possession - health response not criminal. 2) Regulated supply for lower-harm drugs (cannabis, MDMA) - legal production, quality control, no advertising, age restrictions, potency limits. 3) Prescription/medical access for higher-harm drugs for dependent users - heroin-assisted treatment, pharmaceutical alternatives. 4) Continued prohibition of commercial supply for high-harm drugs while treating users as health issue. 5) Massive investment in treatment, housing, mental health - what prohibition currently costs in enforcement. 6) Education that's evidence-based, not scare tactics. 7) Address social determinants - poverty, trauma, housing. 8) Drug checking services for harm reduction. 9) Community input particularly from affected communities including Indigenous. 10) Evaluation and adjustment based on outcomes, not ideology. This acknowledges drugs have different risk profiles requiring different responses, that criminalising users creates harm, but that unregulated commercial markets also create problems.

unistructural.question: What is dual diagnosis?
unistructural.sampleAnswer: Dual diagnosis refers to someone having both a mental health condition and a substance use disorder at the same time.

multistructural.question: List four brain regions or systems affected by addiction.
multistructural.sampleAnswer: The reward system (dopamine pathways, nucleus accumbens), prefrontal cortex (decision-making and impulse control), extended amygdala (stress and negative emotions), and memory systems (hippocampus and basal ganglia for drug-associated memories and habits).

relational.question: Explain the relationship between stigma and help-seeking for drug problems.
relational.sampleAnswer: Stigma creates barriers to help-seeking at multiple levels. Internalised stigma (shame about drug use) prevents people acknowledging they have a problem or deserve help. Anticipated stigma (expecting negative responses) makes people reluctant to disclose to healthcare providers, employers, or family. Structural stigma (discriminatory policies, underfunded services) reduces access to care. Experienced stigma (judgmental treatment from healthcare providers) discourages future help-seeking. The result is that people delay seeking help until problems are severe, reducing treatment effectiveness. Reducing stigma through language change, education, and integrating addiction treatment into mainstream healthcare is essential for improving help-seeking and outcomes.

extendedAbstract.question: Critically analyse why drug policy reform is politically difficult despite evidence suggesting current approaches are ineffective.
extendedAbstract.sampleAnswer: Multiple factors explain this: 1) Moral investment - many people have deeply held beliefs about drugs as moral issue; policy change feels like condoning immorality. 2) Political risk - appearing 'soft on drugs' is electoral liability; tough-on-crime positions are safer. 3) Incumbent interests - law enforcement agencies have institutional interests in maintaining enforcement approach; treatment sector less politically powerful. 4) Media framing - sensationalist coverage makes compassionate approaches hard to advocate; 'what about the children' responses shut down nuance. 5) International constraints - UN drug conventions create legal barriers. 6) Path dependency - existing infrastructure, training, and institutions are built around current approach; change requires rebuilding. 7) Marginalisation of affected voices - people who use drugs are stigmatised and lack political power; decisions made about them, not with them. 8) Evidence complexity - evidence doesn't dictate single correct policy; values interpretation required. 9) Short political cycles - reform requires sustained commitment; benefits take time; costs (if any) more immediate. Change may require: shifting public opinion, building coalitions, framing reform in acceptable terms, incremental approaches that demonstrate safety, and centring evidence while acknowledging values.

studentReflection: How does understanding addiction neurobiology change my view of people with drug problems?
What values underlie different positions in drug policy debates?
How might social factors in my own context affect drug-related outcomes?

E.levelDescription: 2+ years above expected level - Critical engagement with research, theory, global perspectives, and drug policy philosophy
whatYouWillLearn: Critical evaluation of drug-related research
Theoretical frameworks for understanding drug use
Global perspectives on drug policy
Philosophical questions in drug policy

sections.title: Critical Evaluation of Drug Research
sections.content:
Understanding research methods and limitations in drug studies.

Challenges in drug research:

Measurement issues:
- Self-report limitations (recall, social desirability)
- Defining 'use' vs 'misuse' vs 'dependence'
- Measuring harm attribution
- Different survey instruments yield different estimates

Causation vs correlation:
- Drug use associated with mental health issues - but which causes which?
- Confounding variables (trauma predicts both)
- Self-medication hypothesis vs drug-induced illness

Sampling challenges:
- Clinical samples (people in treatment) not representative
- General population surveys miss heavy users
- Hidden populations difficult to study
- Selection effects in longitudinal studies

Ethical constraints:
- Can't randomly assign people to use drugs
- Limits experimental designs
- Observational studies have limitations

Publishing biases:
- Positive findings more likely published
- Industry-funded research may have conflicts
- Dramatic findings get attention over nuanced ones

Evaluating evidence quality:

Hierarchy of evidence:
- Systematic reviews and meta-analyses (strongest)
- Randomised controlled trials
- Cohort studies
- Case-control studies
- Cross-sectional surveys
- Expert opinion (weakest)

Questions to ask:
- What was the sample and how representative?
- How were key variables measured?
- What alternative explanations exist?
- Who funded it and what are their interests?
- Has it been replicated?
- Does it align with other evidence?

sections.title: Theoretical Frameworks
sections.content:
Different theories explain drug use and addiction.

Biomedical theories:

Brain disease model:
- Addiction as chronic brain disorder
- Characterised by compulsion, loss of control, negative emotional state
- Supported by neuroimaging showing brain changes
- Treatment implications: medication, addressing brain pathology
- Critique: deterministic, undervalues social factors and recovery diversity

Genetic vulnerability:
- Addiction runs in families
- Twin studies suggest 40-60% heritability
- Multiple genes involved, no single 'addiction gene'
- Gene-environment interactions crucial

Psychological theories:

Self-medication hypothesis:
- Drug use as attempt to cope with distress
- Specific drugs chosen to address specific symptoms
- Implications: treat underlying issues

Behavioural theories:
- Conditioning and learning
- Positive reinforcement (drug effects)
- Negative reinforcement (withdrawal avoidance)
- Environmental cues as triggers
- Treatment: disrupt conditioning, new learning

Sociological theories:

Social learning theory:
- Drug use learned through observation and modelling
- Peer influence, family modelling
- Media normalisation

Social control theory:
- Drug use more likely when bonds to conventional society are weak
- Employment, family, community ties are protective

Labelling theory:
- Being labelled 'addict' shapes identity and behaviour
- Criminalisation creates deviant identity
- Stigma becomes self-fulfilling

Integrated models:

Biopsychosocial model:
- Biological vulnerability + psychological factors + social context
- Most comprehensive but can be vague

Eco-social framework:
- Individual, interpersonal, community, societal factors interact
- Structural factors emphasised
- Policy implications at each level

sections.title: Global Perspectives
sections.content:
Drug policy varies dramatically across countries.

International framework:

UN Drug Conventions:
- 1961 Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs
- 1971 Convention on Psychotropic Substances
- 1988 Convention Against Illicit Traffic
- Establish international prohibition framework
- Countries required to criminalise
- Tensions with reform approaches

Recent shifts:
- UN acknowledging need to balance health and human rights
- More flexibility in interpretation
- But full legalisation still technically inconsistent with conventions

Comparative policy:

Portugal:
- Decriminalised all personal use (2001)
- Dissuasion commissions instead of courts
- Investment in treatment
- Results: reduced overdose, HIV, incarceration; use stable

Netherlands:
- Cannabis sold through licensed 'coffee shops' (de facto legalisation)
- Other drugs still illegal but pragmatic enforcement
- Harm reduction focus
- Use rates similar to other European countries

Switzerland:
- Heroin-assisted treatment for severe addiction
- Supervised injecting facilities
- Results: reduced crime, improved health, HIV, mortality

Canada:
- Cannabis legalised (2018)
- Supervised consumption sites
- Decriminalisation of all personal use being implemented (2023)

United States:
- State-level cannabis legalisation (varying models)
- Federal level still prohibited
- Mass incarceration driven partly by drug war
- Opioid crisis driving some reform

Asia:
- Generally punitive approaches
- Death penalty for trafficking in some countries
- Limited harm reduction
- Rising methamphetamine issues

Latin America:
- Producer countries bearing costs of 'war on drugs'
- Violence from drug trafficking
- Some countries reforming (Uruguay, Mexico)
- Debate about ending prohibition to reduce criminal market

sections.title: Philosophy of Drug Policy
sections.content:
Fundamental questions underlying drug policy debates.

Autonomy and paternalism:

The autonomy argument:
- Adults should be free to make decisions about their own bodies
- Including decisions that may harm themselves
- Mill's harm principle: law shouldn't prevent self-harm

Paternalist responses:
- Addiction undermines autonomy
- Brain changes mean choices aren't truly free
- Some people can't assess risks adequately
- Children need protection

Middle positions:
- Distinguish informed autonomous choice from constrained choice
- Regulate to protect autonomy (information, quality control)
- Asymmetry between new users and dependent users

Harm to others:

Direct harms:
- Violence, accidents, neglect while intoxicated
- Clearer grounds for intervention
- But alcohol (legal) causes most of these

Indirect harms:
- Healthcare costs
- Lost productivity
- Family impacts
- Counter: these apply to many legal activities

Harm of prohibition:
- Criminal records
- Imprisonment
- Dangerous unregulated supply
- Empowered criminal markets
- Barrier to help-seeking

Justice considerations:

Distributive justice:
- Who bears costs and benefits?
- Enforcement falls on marginalised communities
- Middle-class drug use relatively unpoliced
- Racial and class disparities

Procedural justice:
- Who decides drug policy?
- Are affected communities involved?
- Democratic legitimacy of drug laws

Historical justice:
- Drug laws have racist origins
- Differential enforcement continues
- Reparation considerations

sections.title: Future Directions and Contested Spaces
sections.content:
Emerging issues and ongoing debates in drug policy.

Scientific developments:

Psychedelic research renaissance:
- Psilocybin for depression, end-of-life anxiety
- MDMA for PTSD
- Ayahuasca, ibogaine for addiction
- Challenges: training, access, integration with existing systems
- Tension between medical model and traditional/recreational use

Pharmacological interventions:
- Vaccines against specific drugs (cocaine, nicotine)
- Medications to reduce craving
- 'Sobering-up' drugs
- Ethical questions: consent, mandated use

Genetic and personalised approaches:
- Pharmacogenomics for treatment matching
- Risk prediction
- Privacy and discrimination concerns

Policy trajectories:

Regulated markets:
- Moving from prohibition to regulation
- Challenges: commercial interests, preventing increased use
- Different models: state monopoly, licensed retail, non-profit

Drug checking and safe supply:
- Testing drugs for dangerous adulterants
- Providing known-quality drugs to dependent users
- Expanding during opioid crisis

Global reform:
- Pressure on UN conventions
- Regional divergence
- Impacts of cannabis legalisation spreading

Remaining tensions:

Liberty vs welfare:
- Individual choice vs population health
- Role of government in protection vs paternalism

Medical vs recreational:
- Should recreational use be permitted or only medical?
- Does medical model co-opt broader reform?

Prevention vs harm reduction:
- Should we try to prevent use or just reduce harm?
- Can these coexist?

Local vs global:
- Can individual countries reform within international framework?
- How do producer and consumer countries balance interests?

keyTerms.definition: Framework integrating biological, psychological, and social factors in understanding health conditions including addiction
Sociological theory that being labelled as deviant shapes identity and behaviour
Philosophical position that liberty should only be restricted to prevent harm to others, not self-harm
Restricting people's liberty for their own good, regardless of their wishes
International treaties establishing framework for drug control that countries must implement
Study of how genes affect individual responses to drugs, enabling personalised treatment

caseStudy.title: Psychedelics: Medicine or Drug?
caseStudy.scenario: Following the TGA's decision to allow psilocybin and MDMA for treatment-resistant conditions, debates emerge about what this means. Psychiatrists argue it should remain strictly medical with trained supervision. Indigenous advocates point out traditional use predates Western medicine and shouldn't be medicalised. Reform advocates see it as a step toward broader drug reform. Religious groups raise concerns about altered states. The pharmaceutical industry sees commercial potential. Young people question why they would face criminal charges for substances now deemed therapeutically valuable.
questions: What different interests and values are at stake in this debate?
How does framing psychedelics as 'medicine' vs 'drug' change what seems appropriate?
What are the tensions between medical model and traditional or recreational use?
How might this development influence broader drug policy debates?
What principles should guide psychedelic policy?
caseStudy.keyLearning: Drug categorisation reflects social construction as much as pharmacology. The same substance can be medicine, sacrament, or dangerous drug depending on framing. Medical legitimisation creates access but also controls. Different stakeholders have legitimate but conflicting interests. Policy must navigate competing values and knowledge systems.

remember.question: What are the three main UN Drug Conventions?
remember.sampleAnswer: The 1961 Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs, the 1971 Convention on Psychotropic Substances, and the 1988 Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances.

understand.question: Explain the tension between autonomy and paternalism in drug policy.
understand.sampleAnswer: The autonomy argument holds that adults should be free to make decisions about their own bodies, including decisions that may harm themselves - the government shouldn't interfere with self-regarding actions. The paternalist position argues that some interference is justified to protect people from themselves, especially when addiction undermines the very autonomy being defended, or when people can't adequately assess risks. The tension is about where to draw the line: should government prevent people from harming themselves, or only from harming others? Drug policy sits at this intersection because drug use primarily harms the user but has secondary effects on others.

apply.question: Apply labelling theory to explain how criminalising drug users might increase rather than decrease drug problems.
apply.sampleAnswer: Labelling theory suggests that when someone is officially labelled as deviant (e.g., 'criminal,' 'drug addict'), this label becomes part of their identity. They may be treated differently by others (stigma), lose access to conventional opportunities (employment, housing), and come to see themselves through the label. Once labelled a criminal or addict, conventional pathways become harder, and deviant identity and networks may become more appealing. The criminal justice response - arrest, court, potentially prison - reinforces deviant identity and connections with other labelled people. The prediction is that criminalisation strengthens rather than weakens drug involvement for those caught in the system, and evidence on recidivism and outcomes supports this.

analyse.question: Analyse why evidence alone doesn't determine drug policy.
analyse.sampleAnswer: Drug policy involves value judgments that evidence can inform but not resolve: How much weight should individual liberty have against population health? Whose preferences count when there's conflict? What level of risk is acceptable? What's the appropriate role of government? Evidence can show what outcomes different policies produce, but choosing between outcomes requires values. Evidence is also contested - different stakeholders emphasise different studies, interpret findings differently, and disagree about what outcomes matter. Additionally, policy happens in political context where interests, ideology, and electoral considerations matter. Evidence must compete with moral intuitions, media framing, and institutional interests. Finally, much drug policy was set before current evidence existed and has path-dependency momentum. Evidence is necessary but not sufficient for policy - it must be combined with explicit value deliberation.

evaluate.question: Evaluate the claim that drug laws have always been about social control of marginalised groups rather than public health.
evaluate.sampleAnswer: This claim has substantial support: historical analysis shows drug laws have targeted specific groups - opium laws targeting Chinese immigrants, marijuana laws connected to Mexican and Black communities, crack cocaine disparities reflecting racial politics. Enforcement has always been racially and class-disparate. The most harmful drugs (alcohol, tobacco) remain legal when they're used by dominant groups. However, the claim may be overstated - there are genuine health concerns about drug harms, and some regulations protect public health. Public health rationale has grown over time even if origins were discriminatory. The most defensible position recognises both: drug laws have served social control functions, AND some drug regulations protect health. Acknowledging discriminatory history and current disparities is essential for legitimate policy, but dismissing all concern about drug harm oversimplifies. Reform should address both discriminatory enforcement AND genuine health protection.

create.question: Develop a framework for thinking about when drug policy paternalism is justified.
create.sampleAnswer: Framework for justified paternalism: 1) Graduated by decisional capacity - stronger paternalism for children and those with impaired capacity; adults presumed competent. 2) Proportionality - intervention should be proportionate to harm severity; more intervention for severe, irreversible harms. 3) Less restrictive alternative - use least restrictive means that achieves health goal (information before regulation before prohibition). 4) Procedural requirements - decisions should be democratic, evidence-informed, and include affected voices. 5) Reversibility test - harder to justify restricting liberty when restriction's own harms are irreversible (criminal records, incarceration). 6) Equity consideration - if policy harms marginalised groups more, additional justification required. 7) Self-regarding vs other-regarding - stronger justification for preventing harm to others; weaker for pure self-harm. 8) Coercion gradient - distinguish information provision, incentives, regulations, and prohibition. Application: current prohibition of cannabis for personal adult use probably fails this test; regulation of sales to children doesn't; views on harder drugs are more contested.

unistructural.question: What is Mill's harm principle?
unistructural.sampleAnswer: Mill's harm principle holds that the only legitimate reason to restrict someone's liberty is to prevent harm to others, not to prevent them from harming themselves.

multistructural.question: List four different theoretical frameworks for understanding addiction.
multistructural.sampleAnswer: Brain disease model (neurobiology), self-medication hypothesis (psychological), social learning theory (sociological), behavioural/conditioning theory, genetic/heritability models, labelling theory, and the integrated biopsychosocial model.

relational.question: Explain the relationship between international drug conventions and national drug policy reform.
relational.sampleAnswer: UN Drug Conventions establish international framework requiring signatory countries (almost all countries) to criminalise certain drugs. This creates constraints on national reform - technically, full legalisation violates treaty obligations. Countries have found workarounds: decriminalisation (not technically legalisation), medical access (permitted under conventions), reinterpreting treaty flexibility, or simply violating treaties (cannabis legalisation in Canada, Uruguay, US states). There's tension between national sovereignty and international commitments. The conventions were designed for prohibition and make reform difficult. Recent UN discourse allows more flexibility, but fundamental reform requires either treaty amendment, withdrawal, or critical mass of countries acting independently.

extendedAbstract.question: Critically synthesise arguments about whether addiction undermines the autonomy that justifies drug legalisation, or whether this becomes circular reasoning for prohibition.
extendedAbstract.sampleAnswer: The autonomy-undermining argument: Addiction neurobiologically impairs decision-making capacity. If autonomy justifies allowing drug use, but drug use undermines autonomy, the justification self-defeats. Paternalism to prevent addiction protects future autonomy. The circularity critique: This reasoning can justify any prohibition (alcohol addiction also undermines autonomy). It presumes most use leads to addiction (untrue). It uses outcomes to restrict initial choices. It disempowers people who use drugs by declaring them non-autonomous. Prohibition creates its own autonomy violations (incarceration, criminal records). Synthesis: The argument has some force for highly addictive drugs but becomes circular if used to justify all prohibition. Possible resolutions: distinguish first-time users (autonomous) from dependent users (impaired); use probability-weighted justification (stronger paternalism for drugs with higher addiction risk); focus on protecting capacity to exit rather than preventing entry; recognise that both addiction AND criminalisation undermine autonomy - choose lesser evil. Most sophisticated position: regulate to maintain autonomy (information, quality control, exit support) rather than prohibit to prevent all risk. Acknowledge contested values and avoid either extreme position.
